Players divide themselves into two teams. Each team begins with $500,000, 5000 fans, and a set of playing pieces. They decide which team will be the home team and the game begins. The standard rules of baseball apply.

Both teams ante $50,000 every inning. The ante increases by $25,000 every three innings. The team that scores more runs in the inning will win this pot. The pot rolls over if both teams score an equal number of runs.

Before the result of an at bat is rolled, the defensive team may move its playing pieces on the gameboard to indicate its defensive position. The offensive player rolls the icosikaidihedron, a 22-sided die, to determine the result of the at bat. If a base runner is in the first, second or ninth batting position then the offensive player may try for a stolen base. The game gives the offensive player a fifty-fifty chance of success for a stolen base.

Certain events will allow either team to move its token along the Franchise gameboard. Fans are won and lost here.

The game is over when the baseball game is complete. All fans won by the teams are worth $10 each. The team with more money has won.

30981.name: Lucky Star Gumball Game
30981.description: This game is made up of a large dome ( 10" diameter) shaped like a Gumball Machine. First you fill the outer part of dome with gum balls, then you insert a penny - which puts one of the gumballs into play. You then use all the skill you can to maneuver the gumball to the center hole- if you get it there.. it delivers the gum ball down the chute to you! The TV commercial jingle that was featured in the advertising for this game said : "You pay, you play, you chew away, and save pennies everyday".

30982.description: This is a simple roll and move horse racing game, with the added dimension that the horses need to clear the steeples. The first version I know of is a 1901 edition, but I've only seen a postcard advertising it and not the actual game. There have been a wood version circa 1930 and a paper version date unknown. This list of versions, however, is by no means definitive.
boardgameversion: Chad Valley Pink Top & Bottom Edition
30982.name: Grand National Steeplechase Game

30983.name: Tom Dick & Harry
30983.description: A very cheap version but with the same idea as Jaques’ Ascot. The game consists of a box that houses five card horses and riders: Tom, Dick and Harry – Gert and Daisy as well. The horses are attached to a spindle by cord that winds around the spindle when turned. The horses are set up on the table, the handle turned, and the horses approach the winning post. The speed of the horses depends on the way the cord winds, giving the chance of a different winner each time. The game components are all cardboard or cord

30984.name: Springfrösche
30984.description:
Every player has four round discs with frog pictures on them: a small, 2 medium, and a big disc. Every player tries to catapult the frogs in the packaging tube ("well") or a surrounding area marked with a paper ring ("Neigborhood") - frogs in the well count with point value.

Everyone uses his catapult at the same time, one may collect frogs outside the well again and catapult them again, as long as one player has placed all frogs in the well or neighborhood.

There is also an expansion kit with 2 additional catapults and frogs in 2 additional colors.

30985.name: Varázstorony
30985.description:
Varázstorony (roughly translated: Magical Tower) is a light fantasy wargame published only in Hungary.
Four races struggle for the ruling of the kingdom with the help of their mighty armies and magic: the humans, the orcs, the elves and the dwarves. The one who can collect enough power (control enough areas) and can enter the Tower with his mage will rise victorious.
Each races have different abilities in battle and have their own spells. The usage of magic is limited by the terrain. Because the modularity of the board, differently shaped and sized areas form the map.

30986.name: Caccia al Tesoro
30986.description:
Cluedo-like game from a TV show.
The players try to find treasures and move by helicopter on the map.
Introduced from a famous dj of '80: Jacques "Jocelyn" Antoine.

30987.name: El Morocco
30987.description: El Morocco is based on the movie Casablanca. The object of the game is to be the first player to accumulate $500,000. You can make money to win in many different ways, but the best way is to gamble in one of the four different casinos. You can also get money by scheming and intrigue. Outwit blackmailers, thieves and spies. But beware of ending up on Devil’s Island.

30988.name: Away Across
30988.description:
Described in the book Calculate!, Away Across is a game where players try to connect opposite sides of a 10x10 board of 100 numbers.

Play makes use of a calculator, though can be done by hand. A player selects a square on the board and a number that is entered into the calculator. The second player multiples this number by another number. Play then alternates between players, marking and subtracting values on the board from the running difference with the person who gets the value to zero or lower claiming the set of marked values of his or her color.

The winner is the player who connects his or her two edges of the board with captured sets.

boardgameversion: Whitman Fox in Green Hat Edition
30989.name: Animal Rummy

30990.name: La Chasse au Trésor
30990.description: Adventure game from the '70s based on a TV show. Each player receives a helicopter, site cards and treasure cards. The board shows 5 continents each with 6 sites with possible treasures on them. Helicopters are moved with a die roll but players can only fly their helicopter when they also play a fuel card. Each treasure has a value which is increased if you also have the card of that treasure and decreased if one of your competitors has the treasure card of the discovered treasure. At the end of the game the player who has most points wins, that is not necessarily the person with the most treasures.

30991.description:
Confrontation and Rag'narok merge into one game: Confrontation: The Age of the Rag'Narok. No longer played with single miniatures (Confrontation) or massive units (Rag'narok), each player commands several small units of two to fifteen miniatures. Completely new concepts like Elixir Points and Tactics were added to this game, while it still uses many of the well-known Confrontation traits like an abundance of special abilities and the use of profile cards to determine the activation sequence. The core rules along with profiles for several of the factions are available for download (free of charge) on Rackham's website.

Re-implements:

Confrontation
Rag'narok
30991.name: Confrontation: The Age of the Rag'Narok

30993.name: Pusher's Street
30993.description:
It's an Italian board game about drugs. Mechanics are like monopoly, but the curious thing is the topic... Players are dope dealers trying to buy and sell all kinds of drugs and at the same time they have to avoid police.
You can find more info on www.pushersstreet.com The web site is in Italian.
Price for Italian market is 64€
link to the rules (Italian only): http://nuke.pushersstreet.com/RegoledelGioco/tabid/53/Defaul...

30994.name: Grim Reaper
30994.description:
Grim Reaper is a game where two populations compete for survival.

Pieces have gender, can ‘mate’, give birth, age and die.

The game is won by the player whose population lives longest or who connects two sides of the board.

The longevity of pieces gets around the diagonal cut problem of playing a connection game using a board with squares. This has been solved elsewhere by going into three (physical)- dimensions, - here the extra dimension is time.

The unusual theme of the game keeps it fun whilst also enabling considerable strategic variety and depth.

There is now an Axiom version of the PC game which can now be downloaded from the "Files" section of this page.

30995.name: SaucerZ
30995.description:
You are a member of an advanced alien civilization. Commanding your team of flying saucers, you'll jaunt from planet to planet collecting four different kinds of minerals. You'll use these minerals to build bases. Once you put down a base, it's there for the rest of the game. Your bases allow passage for your saucers - but block saucers belonging to other players. Be the first to build all of your bases and become the champion of the galaxy!

SaucerZ is a light tactical game for 2-4 players. It sets up fast, plays fast, and puts away fast. Specially marked dice determine which planets produce minerals or which planet "orbits" on each player's turn.

30996.name: Up There Cazaly
30996.description:
Up There Cazaly is a 2-player game that simulates the game of Australian Rules Football. Players use cards and dice to control the ball and attempt to score.

Players pick 6 Cazalies to play on 6 of the 22 positions of the field. On your turn you move the ball along one of the routs from position to position. If you have one of your Cazalies at the new position (and your opponent does not), move again. If your opponent has a Cazaly there, they get possession of and move the ball. If there are no Cazalies there, flip an "Umpy" (umpire) card to see who gets possession and the next move.

When you get to one of the positions close to the gaol, roll a dice to see if you score.

This was a licensed VFL (Victorian Football League) product.

Game Contents:

Score pad
44 "Cazaly" Player cards (2 sets of 22 numbered cards)
48 "Umpy" cards
Plastic football
Game board
Six-sided die
Rules insert

30997.name: Fact Finder Fun
30997.description:
Fact Finder Fun (Pinball Game)

Cards are slotted into plastic tray front. Pinballs are loaded inside . Pull the trigger releasing a ball and now look where it is falling and insert the pencil (we have added an alternative as pencil was missing)into the correct answer hole. If you get it right the ball will fall into scoring tray if not it will fall into the discard tray at back.

Take turns
Does anyone know where I can purchase one of these games today I used to love this game as a child ??

30998.name: Showjumping
30998.description:
TO START THE GAME
Showjumping game is kept as close to showjumping rules as possible.

All players start with No Points. Penalty points are given for every fault the player acquires when proceeding around the circuit.

To start the game it will require a player to take score of the penalty points against each player on a sheet of paper. Put down the name of the player and every time the players' horse acquires a fault, put down the penalty points given against the player. All players will throw the dice. the player with the lowest roll will start the game.

PENALTY POINTS
Are given against the player as follows:
a. Knock-downs - 4 points against
b. Refusals - 2 points plus the player moves three spaces backwards.
There are SPECIAL HALTS, BONUS POINTS

TO FINISH
All players must roll the correct number to finish.
The player with the least number of penalty points will be the winner.

30999.name: Ivan the Great: The Rise of Muscovy 1462-1505
30999.description:
HISTORY: Ivan III the Great came to the throne of Muscovy as its Grand Prince on the death of his father Vasily (Basil) II in 1462. Through his cunning diplomacy and well-timed military actions he was responsible over the next 43 years for expanding the state of Muscovy enormously, conquering, annexing, or marrying into the lands of Rostov, Yaroslavl, Ryazan, Novgorod, Vyatka, Tver, and a substantial piece of Lithuania, while forming sturdy alliances with Pskov, the Crimean Tatars, Kazan, and Denmark, and at the same time having to deal with religious controversies and the periodic treacheries of various boyars and even of his own family. His son Vasily III and grandson Ivan IV (the Terrible) extended his remarkable gains even further. Essentially, Ivan single-handedly created what we now know as the Russian nation.

During most of his reign, his most powerful rival was Casimir IV, Grand Prince of Lithuania, although, despite much peripheral conflict, Muscovy and Lithuania did not go to all-out war until 1500, some eight years after Casimir’s death.

OBJECT OF THE GAME: In brief, Muscovy is trying to gain control of or subdue as many countries as possible before the big war with Lithuania, while maintaining high levels on the Ivan's Prestige, Russian Orthodox Church, and Victory Point charts. Some of these countries will become full allies, others will just be reduced so as not to cause serious trouble in Ivan’s rear later on. Once the war with Lithuania begins, Muscovy will try to take over as much territory from Lithuania as he can. (Military success may possibly make up for any shortfalls in the three charts.) The Lithuanian player is simply trying to throw as many monkey wrenches as he can into Muscovy’s plans by keeping up pressure on various fronts, military and geographical (the map) as well as political (the charts).

There is a 22-turn campaign game, and there are five shorter scenarios.

31000.description:
Power Up, Rangers! Power Rangers, the evil Lord Zedd has stolen all of your weapons. Do you have what it takes to battle him and his Evil Space Aliens and get your weapons back?

Game object: Be the first Power Rangers to collect your two weapons and return to the Angel Grove High Gym!

Gameplay: On your turn, roll both dice together. Then move your pawn clockwise along the gamepath the total number shown on the dice. (Players will have to circle the gamepath twice during play.) Follow the direction of the spaces you land on. Note: More than one pawn may occupy the same space.

How to Win: The first player to collect his or her Power Ranger's two Weapon tokens and reach the Angel Grove High Gym is the winner! Go Power Rangers!
31000.name: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: The Revenge of Lord Zedd Game

30501.name: Conni feiert Geburtstag
30501.description:
Conni is having a birthday and all of her friends are invited. Come to the party with them!

Her mother has baked a delicious cake. Everyone wants a piece of it, but only those that have a place at the table with Conni can get a piece of cake.

The clock is set and it begins! This game requires observation and quick reactions.

Contents:

A real clock with bell
5 wooden dice
1 sticker
30 Birthday guests
6 plates
1 Birthday table
1 Little-hippo chip
Instructions





Conni hat Geburtstag und alle ihre Freunde sind eingeladen. Feiert mit !

Ihre Mama hate einen leckeren Kuchen gebacken. Alle wollen etwas davon haben, doch nur, wer einen Platz am Tisch mit Conni ergattert, bekommt ein Stück vom Kuchen ab.

Die Zeit-Uhr wird gestellt und los geht`s ! Bei diesem Spiel sind genaues Schauen und eine schnelle Reaktion gefragt !

Inhalt:

1 echte Zeituhr mit Kuchendruck
5 Holzwürfel
1 Aufkleberbogen
30 Geburtstagsgäste
6 Krümel-Teller
1 Geburtstagstisch
1 Seepferdchen-Chip
1 Anleitung

30502.name: Molimba
30502.description: A two player trick taking game in which the objective is to go out first with a two- or one-suited hand of nine cards. Players start with nine randomly dealt cards and two face down "shed" cards between them. Standard no-trump trick-taking rules apply (with aces high) and the loser of the trick exchanges two of his cards (without revealing them) for the two face down cards.

30503.description:
From Games of Art, Springer is a game based on the artwork of Ferdinand Springer.

The object of the game is to connect all four sides and claim at least a minimum number of points by filling in spaces on the board. Play is restricted not allowing you to fill in a space that shares a side with a space of your color already filled in.
30503.name: Springer

30504.name: The Oxford History of Board Games
30504.description:
"The Oxford History of Board Games investigates the principles of board games throughout the ages and across the world, exploring the fascinating similarities and differences that give each its unique appeal, and drawing out the significance of game-playing as a central part of human experience - as vital to a culture as its music, dance, and tales."

"Beautifully illustrated, and with diagrams to show the finer points of the games, this is a fascinating and accessible guide to a richly rewarding subject"

30505.name: Apples to Apples: British Isles Edition
30505.description:
This edition of the American smash-hit family and party game, Apples to Apples, contains hundreds of new cards specifically designed for players from the British Isles and those familiar with the area, and its cultures and history.

756 Red Apple Cards
252 Green Apple Cards

Part of the Apples to Apples Series.

30506.name: Plunder
30506.description: A three-player trick taking game in which each player gains control of an exposed dummy after winning a trick. The trump suit for the hand changes depending on which player controls the dummy.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Charles S. Roberts Best Wargame Graphics Nominee
2007 Charles S. Roberts Best World War II Boardgame Nominee
30507.description:
(from publisher's page)

OVERLORD: D-Day and the Beachhead Battles is an expansion module for The Killing Ground that covers the period from June 6, to July 5, 1944. This 30 game-turn module links directly to The Killing Ground with an additional map, playing pieces and rules. It may also be played as a single map, stand alone game. In either case, the original The Killing Ground game is required to use this module.

OVERLORD: D-Day and the Beachhead Battles is divided into three stages, each with a different sequence of play.
1. D-Day: June 6, 1944
2. OVERLORD: The Build-up
3. The Killing Ground

D-Day: June 6th, 1944 sequence of play is used only on game-turn one. OVERLORD: The Build-up sequence of play starts on turn 2 and ends the Game-turn in which both Allied nationalities have completed their depots. The Killing Ground sequence of play starts the turn after the depots are completed. The rules from the original Killing Ground game are used throughout the Build-up except were noted. The rules for D-Day and OVERLORD are in addition to and supersede the standard Killing Ground rules until the end of the Build-up.

The OVERLORD expansion module includes the following:

24 page OVERLORD Rules Booklet
D-Day Turn 1 Sequence of Play Booklet
2nd edition Killing Ground Rules Booklet
North map section ; 22" x 34" (2 sided)
280 back-printed, die cut counters (1/2 inch)
Game Turn Record Track
Sequence of Play Card (2 sided)
Breakdown Battalion recombination guide
German Set-up card
D-Day and Build-up Charts and Tables card




(The following are not yet mentioned on the publisher's site, but are also included...)

Combat Manual Pamphlet
Guide to Replacement Counters
Allied Tracks and Tables Single Map Supplement Card
CRT Card




Most units are regiments with armor and other assets as battalions. At one day per turn and 2.5 km a hex.

Expands:

The Killing Ground
30507.name: Overlord: D-Day and the Beachhead Battles

30508.name: Spyhunting
30508.description:
Spyhunting is a 2-player strategy game whereby one player acts as the hunter and one player is hunted a.k.a. the spy.

This game can be played with standard equipment (checkerboard) from the average gamer collection in addition to some non-standard dice.

The spy’s objective is to travel from one corner to the opposite corner and back without being “shot.” The hunter’s objective is to “shoot” the spy before he or she accomplishes his or her objective.

This game was a Top 11 finalist in the 2002 Board Game Design Competition called "Simultaneous Action Design" awarded by About.Com.

30509.name: Odds And Evens
30509.description:
Odds and Evens is a 2-player strategy game that can be played with components found in the average gamer collection.

The object of the game is to be the first player to move all of your pieces to the opponent's home row.

Players take turns rolling two six-sided dice and moving pawns on a standard checkerboard. A unique rule to the game completely eliminates any advantage earned of one player rolling better dice combinations.

30510.name: Luck O' The Irish
30510.description:
From the Rules: THE LUCK O' THE IRISH is the game for Kings of Ireland, Leprechauns, Fairies, and the Little Folk. It is played by means of pieces being moved around the playing board, Ireland, according to throw of the dice.

The players set off from Dublin taking any road they wish and on their journey around Ireland must collect a Pot of Gold, a Harp, a Shamrock, a Shillelagh, and an Emerald. The first player to return to Dublin with all five items is the winner.

On their journey player will visit the historical cities of Ireland , cross the River Shannon, find their Pot of Gold at the end of the Rainbow, ride in the Jaunting Car and encounter that mischievous elf of Irish folk-lore the Leprechaun.

But beware there are pitfalls of which the most ferocious is the Banshee.

To win you will need "THE LUCK O' THE IRISH"

30511.name: Rattlesnake City
30511.description:
You arrive at Rattlesnake Valley where you build a saloon with your last dollars.
With Rattlesnake City you will discover an exalted life, reconstructed cities, big ranches, old gold mines and a run-down rail way.
You will loot the banks, winning (perhaps) a game of poker and, most of all, you will not save up your bullets.
All means and ways to become the richest man in the west and the mayor of Rattlesnake City are welcome...

The game material consists of:
• The board that shows the valley, some ruins and the rail way
• 1 740 000 $ (in 120 bills)
• 90 bullets (in 54 cards)
• Cowboys, Mexicans, beautiful women, whiskey, tar and feathers, a set of poker cards
• Saloons, banks, mines, schools, hotels, general stores, sheriff, railway stations, churches, cemeteries and 72 pieces of rails track
• 36 wooden markers, a cloth bag, 2 rules overview and a full rules booklet

30512.name: Pigeon Poop
30512.description:
Mr. Boneyhead is late for work. He just lives down the road from his office. It'd be all so easy except for the pesky pigeon who has taken such a dislike to him.

As the pigeon you must drive Mr. Boneyhead off the street's end. Use any of the tricks that your cards may allow you or... well... use what nature gave you in the end.

As Mr. Boneyhead you must make it to work period. Use your umbrella and whatever the street offers up to you in order to get there. And if you're of a nasty frame of mind... pluck that pigeon's feathers for him. Take enough from his tail and he'll leave you alone while the other birds laugh at his fashion faux pas.

Pigeon Poop... you're in my sights now.

30513.name: Zombie Basketball
30513.description:
Zombie Basketball...

Enjoy the horror, the humour and the blood and guts of a game played by brave young men and shambling undead zombies.

Play against a friend or by yourself.

As a zombie team you can recruit new players from the opposing team... your bite is infectious and there is no cure.

As a human team... will your sharpshooter be good enough to keep the zeds off your back when you're going for the layup?

Try the game and claim some fame.

Zombie Basketball... are you man or are you meat?

30514.description: Solitaire dice game in which you get to throw the dice exactly 30 times. If you are efficient with your early tosses, you can use your saved throws to improve your score.

30515.name: Peek-a-boo Rummy
30515.description: A two-player Rummy variant where certain discards force cards in the draw deck to be exposed.

30516.name: Flash
30516.description: Flash is a card game for two to five players. Play is much like Rummy, but the emphasis is on sequences. In fact, the player with the longest sequence at the end of the hand is the only player to score. Melds of three and four of a kind are useful, however; they are immediately replaced by a like number of cards from either the stock or the discard pile.

30517.description:
Crossway is played with a Go set. White's goal is to connect the left and right edges of the board with a contiguous sequence of stones, and Black's goal is to connect the top and bottom edges. Unlike Go, you can connect diagonally, so there are eight directions of connectivity in Crossway.

You can’t crosscut, so if your opponent already has connected two stones diagonally adjacent, you’re not allowed to place a stone that would create two mutually crossing adjacent diagonals.

Draws and ties cannot occur in Crossway.
30517.name: Crossway

30518.name: Palisade
30518.description:
Palisade is played with a Go set. Points available to Player 1 are interspersed with points available to Player 2 in a checkerboard pattern. When you form a loop which surrounds enemy stones, you remove the enemy stones from the board. Neither player may place stones into a loop. A player owns the perimeter of his loop as well as all of the points contained within the loop. When all of the board points, both occupied and unoccupied are owned by the players, the game is concluded and the player who owns the majority of points wins.

Rule sheet:
http://www.marksteeregames.com/Palisade_rules.pdf

Online Play


Super Duper Games

30519.name: BackRound
30519.description:
From The Intro - What is a BackRound? A BackRound is a word pronounced backwards. For example: the BackRound for 'table' is 'leb-bait'. Some BackRounds are made up of actual words like 'eat-is' (which is the word 'city', pronounced backwards).

The first player to collect 5 cards (if team play you must collect 10 cards) wins the game.

30520.name: The Winery Game
30520.description: From the Intro - The Winery Game is designed to be played by 2 to 6 players, each representing a different winery. The object is to generate the most profits before eight of the twelve markets are filled to capacity. This is done by buying grapes, bottling them into wine cases and selling the wine to the markets spaced around the board.

30521.name: Octagram
30521.description: Word game which uses 40 octagonal tiles with letters on them. Players draw and play a tile at a time to form words. In addition to forming words by adding to the existing layout, one or more lines of letters can be removed and replaced to form a word as well, although each word may only be scored once throughout the game. Can also be played as a solo challenge.

30522.name: Tank Trap
30522.description: Although ostensibly about battles between tanks, this game is really an abstract strategy game with some superficial similarities to checkers. The game is played between two players who respectively move their tank pieces on an grid of squares in an effort to trap and destroy the other tanks. While the game has some interesting rules for movement and capture, the components are rather low budget--small cardboard circles for the tanks and a fold out paper map.

30523.name: You're Talking Absolute...Football
30523.description: This is a football (soccer) trivia game. The game includes a plastic ball with electronics which operates as a timer and a noisemaker. Teams of players compete to answer questions to be the first to score seven goals and win the match. Red and yellow penalty cards can be given to players on the opposing team.

30524.name: The Eton Game
30524.description:
This is a roll and move game using the theme of students attending the very exclusive Eton College in England. Players begin with four "colour cards" representing a different facet of life at Eton - artistic, sporting, social and academic. They must then work their way round a stylised map of the college, getting rid of all their cards to become the winner. A variety of penalties can be imposed for bad behavior, including a "faux pas" for things such as hitting a teacher with a snowball, or allowing one's mother to turn up at school in an embarrassing hat.

The game was invented by an Eton housemaster and his assistant, both old boys of the school themselves.

30525.name: Wall Street
30525.description: This is a solitaire-type game. The playing field is a row of twelve "gold" bars and the playing pieces are miniature bulls and bears. The game involves rolling a die to move and remove the playing pieces from the bars. This was produced as an executive-style game, as all of the pieces and the die are silver plated.

30526.name: Crazy Post
30526.description: This is a party game which mixes word play with a hunt. The game involves posting the correct letter into the correct post box. The letters and mailboxes have similar spelled or sounding names, which makes the job quickly putting the right letter in the right mailbox more challenging that it would first seem. The winner is the person posting the greatest numbers of letters correctly. The game consists of eight cardboard post boxes and 384 letters.

30527.name: Sixteen
30527.description:
Sixteen is an original card game for two players, ages 8 and older. It is easy to learn (about 5 minutes) and takes about 15 minutes to play, though players will find themselves wanting to play again and again before they put the deck away.

Each player is dealt three cards. The remaining cards are placed face-down in the middle of the table as the draw pile. The cards are numbered 0-6. There are two of every card, but only one zero card for each suit. There are also two wild cards. Players take turns, picking a card, and then adding a card to a fanned-out, face-up play pile.

There are two ways to win a set: when the face-up cards total 16, or when the last three cards in the win pile are all the same color or number. So, you have to pay a lot of attention to what's in the pile, as well as what's in your hand, as well as make some educated guessing about what could very possibly be in you-know-who's hand. If the play pile goes over 16, a "bust" is declared and the other player gets the win. The player with the most sets when all cards have been played wins the round.

All of this results in some rather delicious strategic implications. The game can become quite competitive, but the elegance of the game, and the element of luck, keep the competition focused, and light-hearted.

The instructions describe four optional play variations, one of which extends the game play to younger children (perhaps as young as 6), but the game plays best with the recommended ages.

30528.name: The Leeds United Football Game
30528.description: This is a soccer game using the team and players of Leeds United. The game focuses on the placement of players on the board and uses a combination of die rolling and card drawing to establish player movement and goal scoring. In addition to winning matches, players also focus on accumulating the largest amount of money.

30529.name: Full On NRL
30529.description: NRL (the National Rugby League of Australia) present Full On NRL. The object (as in proper rugby) is to score as many tries and conversions as possible, moving your thirteen players around the board using the Direction Dice. Each of the league's 16 teams are represented in the game as you play the Telstra Premiership or just for fun.

30530.name: Happy Traveler
30530.description: Players draw a card and list as many answers as possible in 60 seconds, receiving one point for every answer. Categories are similar to those on Family Feud, such as, "Things you eat raw." Cards offer three levels of difficulty.

30531.name: Wings for the Baron
30531.description:
Wings for the Baron is a game of designing and manufacturing World War I aeroplanes. It uses cards to represent the various aeroplane technnologies and random events of the period.

The mechanics are simple: each turn, the players secretly choose two actions to perform: Build (to construct factories), Spy (to acquire other players' technologies, Design (to construct a new type of aeroplane), Research (to get more cards), or Bank (to protect assets from inflation). Since selection is simultaneous and the actions are quick to resolve there is very little downtime.

After resolving actions, the players are awarded points based on the quality of their aeroplane design and their industrial capacity; then a War Status card is drawn to randomly affect the progress of the war. The game ends when the war does, so timing and efficiently using your actions are important factors in victory.

The game typically lasts about 30 minutes.

Wings for the Baron is available from the designer at the game's web site. Compared to the playtest version, previously distributed for free, this desktop-published game has rules edited for clarity, ten pages of historical notes, more easily distinguished colors, and fully-illustrated cards.

30532.name: Muntslag
30532.description:
English translation from the box:

Muntslag are a tense tactical game, where by buying and selling of currencies, the player can create the winning collection.

The first player who has collected a series of currency on the market is the winner. The player builds its series of currency by buying and selling currencies on the market and trading with other players.

30533.description:
Under the Black Flag is the first supplement to the Gloire: Swashbuckling Adventure in the Age of Kings rules, and it covers swashbuckling pirate adventure in the Caribbean in the golden age of the buccaneers.

The book includes rules for creating campaigns of linked games, which will allow players to advance their model’s skills and abilities. Rules are also included for sailing and boarding ships, so players can swing from the rigging as they take galleons loaded with gold, or fire a broadside from a pirate sloop. Almost two dozen new character archetypes are introduced, as well as new abilities and skills. Seven scenarios round out the book-tales of treasure buried hastily on desert islands, mutinies, and divided loot gone amiss.

Sharpen your cutlass and prime your pistol, for we leave the world of the kings’ laws and sail Under the Black Flag!

Expands:

Gloire: Swashbuckling Adventure in the Age of Kings
30533.name: Under the Black Flag: Swashbuckling Action on the High Seas

30534.name: Pop-Dog
30534.description: Players pop a die and turn a block of the same color shown on the die. The winner is the first to construct a picture of Pop Dog.

30535.name: World's Best Dice Games
30535.description:
Detailed book explaining rules for 80+ dice games and variants. Fully illustrated with odds tables, score sheets, photos, cartoons and playing examples.

Games include

Boss Dice (and variants - including "Bogey's game"),
Liars Dice (and variants),
Captain Ship and Crew, or Monterey
Games you Keep Score in - Yacht, Ten Thousand, Crag, Hooligan, and Chicago
Popular Games - Intelligence, Red Dog, Mafia, Aces, and Poker Dice
Games for Children - Drop Dead, Indian Chief, Matterhorn, Racetrack, and Wipe Out
International Favorites - Bardudey (Greece), Shingoro (Japan), Heaven and Nines (China), Mandando (Phillippines), and Dudo (South America)

30536.name: Educated Guess
30536.description:
Educated Guess - Drawing game. Divide everybody up into two teams (there are rules for 3 players). Players alternate as the DRAWER and try to get their team to guess what they are drawing.

Both teams may guess every round. If the DRAWER's team guesses correctly then they move ahead one space. If the opposing team guesses then the DRAWER's team is blocked. There is no time limit for drawing/guessing. If nobody can guess correctly the DRAWER will choose a new 'Type Of' card to draw.

The board is made up of 5 Greek Letter - Pi, Delta, Theta, Sigma and Omega. Depending on which Greek Letter your pawn is on determines the 'Type Of' clue to be drawn.

The first team to the 'Omega' WIN space is the winner.

30537.name: Press Your Luck
30537.description: A fast-paced family game played with eight, 8-sided dice with similarities to the games Farkel and Fill or Bust! Players strive to roll three or more of a kind or a one, five, or straight. Bonuses and busts help or hinder the player on their way to be the first to score 10,000 points.

30538.name: Dateline The History Game
30538.description: Dateline The History Game is an educational historical trivia game. Players compete to provide the correct historical date of events, and then use number tiles to construct that date in a sort of crossword/scrabble type arrangement. The game's components are cards with the history questions on them and cardboard tiles with numbers on them.

boardgamehonor: 2011 Origins Awards Best Family, Party or Children’s Game Nominee
2011 Origins Awards Best Family, Party or Children’s Game Winner
2013 As d'Or - Jeu de l'Année Nominee
30539.description:
"You don't have to be faster than the shark, just faster than your friends!"

Get Bit! is a card game where players are competing to stay alive as the others are being eaten by the shark.

The order of the swimmers is determined by simultaneously playing cards face-down then revealing the values. The number on each player's card determines position in line (higher numbers in front, lower numbers in back), however ties don't move. The swimmer at the back loses a limb to the shark and is flung to the front of the line! The process is repeated until only two swimmers remain on the table. When this happens, the swimmer at the front of the line wins the game!
boardgameversion: French third edition in tin box
German third edition in tin box
30539.name: Get Bit!
boardgameaccessory: Get Bit / Walk the Plank: Dual Purpose Playmat
Get Bit!: Sticker Attire and Faces
boardgamepodcastepisode: Aeroplanos con Wallace. Sobrevolamos el Peloponeso
Dukes of Dice - Ep. 45 - The Quilting Guild
Episode 33 : Gencon 2016 Recap + Interview with Ryan Bruns (Mayday Games)
Episodio 4 – Get Bit!, Inventum y Essen 2011
Episodio 6 – A Touch of Evil y ¿tema o mecánica?

30540.name: Moon Probe
30540.description: This is a space race game consisting of a playing board depicting the flight to the moon, six different coloured plastic space ships, a set of instructions, and a dial with spinner. The first player to reach the moon and then make the return journey to earth is the winner. The game board is marked with a variety of bonuses and hazards that have consequences for the players as their moon probes make the journey.

30541.name: Squarem
30541.description: This game consists of a multi-colored checkerboard and four sets of cardboard counters. The objective of the game is to complete as many squares as possible. The basic way to do this is to fill in all four sides of a square with your counters and then place a fifth counter in the bed of the square so formed.

30542.name: Eamonn Andrews Presents Questo
30542.description:
'Questo' is a question and answer game that traded on the popularity of the then very young Irish television presenter Eamonn Andrews. It consists of a slotted spinning disc that reveals a letter through the slot when it stops, and a pack of 48 question cards. The first player to answer the question on the card correctly with an answer beginning with the letter disclosed is given the card. The winner is the player who has the greatest number of cards at the end of the game.
Eamonn Andrews also presented "What's my line?" and "This is your life", amongst many others in his career.

30543.name: Word Making and Taking
30543.description:
"The Popular Spelling Game"

This game uses cardboard letter tiles that have the upper case letter on one side and the lower case letter on the other. The game includes rules for using these tiles in 21 different word games, including spelling games, anagram games, scrabble-like games, and hangman-like games.

30544.name: Houp-la
30544.description: A children's game which uses the theme of a hoop toss at a carnival. This boxed game includes two rows of cardboard stand-ups featuring toys and items of the period and four rubber rings.

30546.name: Charge! or How to Play War Games
30546.description:
Originally published in 1967 in Britain, Charge! is one of two foundation texts establishing the modern miniatures war game hobby. Many of those who play miniatures began with this book and almost all existing rules systems can trace their lineage back to this book.

The book is a detailed building up of rules for playing a war game. It contains detailed discussion of the rationale behind these rules, grounding them in military theory and history. The book contains two sets of rules: an elementary set for playing simple games and an advanced set of rules to provide a richer simulation. It also contains one scenario, a mythical 18th century battle, which is played out step by step in the book.

These rules define the "Old School" of war gaming: individually based figures in large units with written orders to sub-commanders, etc. Despite its age, there are groups of gamers who continue to base their encounters on the spirit of this book if not its strict letter.

30548.description:
The game consists of a base with eight large plastic tower sections which are built up into a leaning tower. Each tower segment has 16 columns molded on the side and these are aligned before the game starts.

The simplest game consists of rolling two dice to find the tower segment to be rotated and how many columns it is to be rotated, either clockwise or counter-clockwise. The player who causes the tower to collapse loses the game.

In the more advanced version, players may choose which tower segment to rotate and by how much - between 1 and 3 columns - and the player scores 1 point for each column rotation.

In the final version of the game, players chose a tower element for the player on the left to use and all players are involved in constructing the tower before rotation begins.

(Note: The English language rules don't state that you cannot reverse the last move made. This is compulsory to make the game playable. For the simplest game, if the same tower segment is chosen, then it must be rotated in the same direction as the last move. Alternately, you can use a House Rule that states that the towers can only be rotated clockwise.)
30548.name: Pisa

boardgamehonor: 2008 Golden Geek Best 2-Player Board Game Nominee
2008 Golden Geek Best Board Game Artwork/Presentation Nominee
2008 Golden Geek Best Family Board Game Nominee
2008 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee
2008 Golden Geek Best Party Board Game Nominee
2008 International Gamers Awards - General Strategy; Multi-player Nominee

2008 JoTa Best Cooperative Board Game Winner

2008 Tric Trac d'Argent
2008 Tric Trac Nominee

2009 Boardgames Australia Awards Best International Game Winner
2009 Deutscher Spiele Preis Best Family/Adult Game 3rd Place

2009 Gouden Ludo Winner

2009 Spiel der Spiele Hit für Experten Recommended
2009 Spiel des Jahres Nominee
2009 Vuoden Peli Adult Game of the Year Nominee
2010 Australian Games Association Game of the Year
2011 Ludoteca Ideale Official Selection Winner
2015 Hungarian Board Game Award Nominee
30549.description:
In Pandemic, several virulent diseases have broken out simultaneously all over the world! The players are disease-fighting specialists whose mission is to treat disease hotspots while researching cures for each of four plagues before they get out of hand.

The game board depicts several major population centers on Earth. On each turn, a player can use up to four actions to travel between cities, treat infected populaces, discover a cure, or build a research station. A deck of cards provides the players with these abilities, but sprinkled throughout this deck are Epidemic! cards that accelerate and intensify the diseases' activity. A second, separate deck of cards controls the "normal" spread of the infections.

Taking a unique role within the team, players must plan their strategy to mesh with their specialists' strengths in order to conquer the diseases. For example, the Operations Expert can build research stations which are needed to find cures for the diseases and which allow for greater mobility between cities; the Scientist needs only four cards of a particular disease to cure it instead of the normal five—but the diseases are spreading quickly and time is running out. If one or more diseases spreads beyond recovery or if too much time elapses, the players all lose. If they cure the four diseases, they all win!

The 2013 edition of Pandemic includes two new characters—the Contingency Planner and the Quarantine Specialist—not available in earlier editions of the game.

Pandemic is the first game in the Pandemic series.
30549.name: Pandemic
boardgameaccessory: Pandemic: Set of Pawns for Roles
boardgamepodcastepisode: 22 Devon Dice podcast Another VAST episode controlled by Turtles and Mechs
25 – The Family Gamers Podcast – Solo play
BGA Episode 100 - Top 100 Games of All Time
BGB Volume 77 - Q&A with Matt Leacock at Orccon 2010
DdJ 015. Protos y Tipos 2013. Homoludicus. Ojo al dado
Dukes of Dice Podcast - Ep. 43 - Kanban Pun

GameBreak Audio Episode #014 - I Get By with a Little Help From My Friends
Gaming Done Right – Episode 4: Time has No Meaning
Garrett's Games 385 - Essen from the Floor, Eggs of Ostrich, Sushi Draft, and Pandemic on the iPad
Gen Can’t 2015 at Cloud Cap Games!
Low Player Count - Ep 11 - High Player Count for Two
Low Player Count - Ep 20 - Our Top 5 Solo Games
Low Player Count - Ep. 21 - Our Top 5 Two Player Games

What Did You Play This Week Podcast Thing Week 42!!! Featuring Patrick Hillier and Eric Booth!
What Did You Play This Week Podcast Thing Week 76
Wooden Cubes & Iron Soldiers: “Boardgames are lame!” Episode 14

30550.name: Sexdrive
30550.description:
From the manufacturer:

Sex Drive is the rollicking adult game that challenges sexual know-how, show-how, and tell-how. Starting on the Outer Course, players answer questions or perform Body Shop tasks to show what they know about sex. The goal is to obtain your Sex Driver’s License, move to the Inner Course, and win by collecting certificates of knowledge from all 8 categories. Categories include women’s issues (Keeping A-Breast), men’s issues (Getting A-Head), sexual myths and fables (Trojan Horse Misconceptions), true or false statements (True or Phallus), and unusual or non-traditional practices (Pressed and Repressed). Players landing in the Body Shop will use hands-on skills to sculpt, draw, or act out their sexual knowledge. So grab a hot rod, hit the road and prove how much you know about Sex Drive!

30551.name: The Clash of Armor
30551.description: Tactical WWII miniatures rules, emphasising tank on tank combat.

30553.name: Ancient Warfare
boardgameversion: A to Z Rules First edition 1988
30553.description:
There is no text on the back of the book. An excerpt from the Author's Notes inside is as follows:

"A to Z Rules For Ancient Warfare is a fast playing set of rules for 25mm and 15mm miniatures. It is compatible with all basing systems, army organizations and army lists. It will enable you to play a game with 300 to 400 figures per side in about four hours.

The heart of the rules is the initiative-impulse movement system, the command control system and the morale system. These are the most critical areas determining the flow of the game. They are also areas of great flexibility and changes can easily be made to meet the requirements of different army compositions or scenarios."

30554.name: The Age of Fighting Sail
30554.description: Naval miniatures rules for the Napoleonic period. Single ship to Fleet Actions. Trafalgar fought in 6 hours by 30 players. Single ship engagements last from 10 to 20 minutes. Easy to learn, fast playing.

30555.name: The American Civil War 1861-1865
30555.description: A brief description from inside the book is as follows: "The A to Z Rules for the American Civil War is the second in series of fast playing rules for 15mm and 25mm miniatures. It is compatible with all basing systems and can be played on a regimental or brigade level. It will enable you to lay a short scenario in three hours or recreate a massive day long battle in brigade scale within five to six days.

30556.name: The Campaigns of Napoleon
30556.description: The A to Z Rules, the Campaigns of Napoleon 1796-1815, is the fourth in a series od fast playing rules for historical miniatures. It is compatible with all basing systems and can be played on a battalion, regimental, or brigade scale. It will enable you to play a short scenario in three hours or recreate a massive day long battle in brigae scale within five to eight hours. The heart of the rules are the intiative and action allocation systems. Combined with morale variables, these are the most critical areas determinging the flow of the game. They are also areas of great flexibility and changes can be made to recreate local conditions, commander capabilities, or scenario anomalies.

30557.name: March of Eagles
30557.description: Tactical miniature wargames rules for the Napoleonic period.

boardgamepublisher: And That's The Way It Was...
30558.description:
Tactical colonial miniatures rules.

Expands:

The Sword and the Flame
30558.name: Eight Hundred Fighting Englishmen

30559.name: Honour and Fortune
30559.description: Interesting umpired miniatures ruleset based on Colonial campaigns in India in the 19th Century.

30560.name: Science vs Pluck
30560.description:
Subtitled: or, Too Much for the Mahdi.

Unusual set of umpired miniatures rules depicting late 19th Century Colonial Campaigns in Africa.

In essence, the referee plays the part of the Mahdists while each player takes the part of an individual officer commanding part of a British force in the Sudan. This is done to simulate the asymmetrical nature of Colonial fighting in that region: the British often had an overwhelming advantage in firepower but were travelling through unknown territory and facing enemies of unknown number.

30561.name: 1644 (second edition)
30561.description: Rules for English Civil War wargames with army lists and campaign system. 2nd Edition is revised and amended.

30562.name: American Civil War Wargaming
30562.description: An introductory book on American Civil Wargames, with miniatures. Full rules set included.

30563.name: Napoleonic Wargaming
30563.description: An introductory book on Napoleonic Miniatures Wargames, including basic history and a full set of tactical rules.

30564.name: Tac WWII
30564.description: Tactical WWII miniatures rules emphasising command and control issues.

30565.name: Principles of War: 18th Century
30565.description: Tactical Miniatures rules for the 18th Century period.

30566.name: British Grenadier!
30566.description:
Tactical miniatures rule set focusing on the American War of Independence. Rule system adapted from General de Brigade.

Title: British Grenadier! - Gaming the Wars for America 1775-1783
By: Eclaireur
Pages: 80 pages with 4 color pages + 4 pages of card play sheet
Size: A4 format - (21cm x 30cm)
Type: Paperback book
Publisher: Partizan Press
ISBN: 1-85818-535-1

30567.name: Ge Koku Jo
30567.description:
From the rulebook's back cover:

"Ge Koku Jo is a fast-paced game of Samurai skirmish. No need for massive armies. No need for memorizing long lists of arcane details. Ge Koku Jo makes building your forces simple and flexible and gets right to the excitement of battle and command. Usable at a variety of scales and sizes, games can be played in under two hours."

30568.name: Festung Krieg
30568.description: Siege miniatures rules for the Seven Years War in Europe.

30569.name: Koenig Krieg
30569.description:
Campaign miniatures rules for the Seven Years War in Europe.

From the publisher's website:

"Koenig Krieg is a set of war game rules that represents the times of Frederick the Great King of Prussia; hence the name Koenig Krieg or Kings War in English. The time we are specifically looking at is the period from 1733 when Frederick was a young man, discussing tactics with The Holy Roman Empire's premier, but old General, Eugene, all the way through to the end of the Seven Years War in 1763.

If you enjoy the history of this time where lace and luck, fire and fury dominated the continent of Europe specifically and the world generally then wargaming with Koenig Krieg is for you........"

30570.name: Der Grosse Koenig
30570.description: Tactical miniatures rules for the Seven Years War in Europe.

30571.name: Katana
30571.description: Tactical miniatures rules for Samurai battles.

30572.name: Then Place My Parboiled Head Upon A Stake
30572.description: An interesting set of tactical miniatures rules ralting to the Montrose Rebellion. Yes, the title is correct!

30573.name: Caddyshack Trivia Game
30573.description:
From the publisher:

Tee off at the Bushwood Country Club with CADDYSHACK Trivia. It’s golf with a CADDYSHACK twist!

Do you know…
How much the final bet was on the big match?
What college Danny wants to attend?
What time the Caddies are allowed to use the pool on Caddy Day?

“Stop thinking, let things happen, and be the ball.”

Play a round-or two-of CADDYSHACK trivia with over 1,000 trivia questions, but don’t let the loudmouth club members, dancing gophers, or the floating doodie distract you! Remember, in the immortal words of Ty Webb, “Me winning isn't. You do.”

Ages 13+
2+ players or teams

30574.name: Lion of the North
30574.description: An innovative tactical rule set based on the 30 Years War.

30576.name: Rampant Colonialism
30576.description: Miniatures rules for the Colonial Period (late 19th Century).

30577.name: Gunfight!
30577.description: Miniatures rules for the Old West - Cowboys, gunslingers, Civil War, and Indians.

30578.name: Starship!
30578.description: A miniatures ruleset for science fiction, ship to ship actions.

30579.name: Screaming G.I.'s
30579.description: An innovative set of WWII skirmish rules.

30580.description:
Known as Khet Mezzanine prior to release, this is a "second-story expansion" or tower for the Khet base game. Innovention president Luke Hooper was said to have pointed to the Battle of Kadesh between Egyptian and Hittite forces as an inspiration for the name.

At the top and bottom of the tower are a collection of mirrors that direct the lasers up and down four separate paths that connect an upper platform to the standard board. Not only can pieces move on that platform, but the entire platform can be moved and rotated.

Expands:

Khet: The Laser Game
30580.name: Khet 3D: Tower of Kadesh

30581.name: Wheel of Fortune Solitaire
30581.description:
The object of the game is to get all the cards in their proper places according to the month on the Wheel Of Fortune. Each position will end up having three different cards, face up, that correspond to it. Interesting early Edu-Tainment game. Not related to Game Show --- this came out before it did.

Game components include : 2-piece puzzle-fit Gameboard, 42 Wheel of Fortune cards (3 ea. of the 12 months & 6 Wheel of Fortune) and instructions.

One player. Ages 6 - 12. Ed-U-Cards from 1966.

30582.description:
Players get a card with a list of "answers". A theme is picked randomly. One player chooses an answer and rings the bell that comes with the game.
He asks a question "in the theme" to the other players, who must answer the correct word. The asking and the answering players earns points. More points are given if some players give the wrong answer before the right one is picked, so the question should not be too easy !
30582.name: Good Question!

30583.description:
Players compete to uncover a secret code consisting of three elements, each of which may be one of four colors. They do this by taking actions determined by the roll of three Treehouse dice. Rules for this game were initially released in July 2007 as part of the 3HOUSE booklet; it is played using three complete Treehouse sets. It is unrelated to the Icehouse expansion of the same name released in 2000.

Also included in Pyramid Arcade.
30583.name: Black Ice

30584.name: Taxi Brousse
boardgameversion: Jeux & Stratégie Nouvelle Formule magazine edition
30584.description:
Each player is a taxi driver in Africa.
The winner is the first player to arrive in Tchoukoutou with 30 000 F CFA to buy a new car to replace his old Peugeot breack 404 : a true Toyota minibus manufactured in Nigeria in Peugeot factories with Mercedes components coming from Libanon

30586.name: Pick-Up Lines
30586.description:
From the manufacturer:

In Pick-Up Lines, players secretly write down their best responses to a pick-up line. Read the one you have out loud and score points if your line is chosen as the best. "Do you know what time it is?" "Time to get to know you better!" Outrageous every time you play - and unique with each gathering of friends. Plastic martini glasses, a shaker and olives add special twists to the fun.

For 3 to 6 adult players or teams.

30587.name: Omega Warrior
30587.description:
From the back of the book:

"By the year 2750, the 150 year old galaxy-wide war had escalated to the point where casualties were measured in millions per day. Entire populations were wiped out and planets made uninhabitable by the fallout of warfare. Faced with annihilation, both sides (the United Democratic Planets or UDP and the Republic of Soviet-Socialist Planets or RSSP)developed an alternative method of waging war. Their solution was the Omega Suit.

"The Omega Suit represents the ultimate development of military technology. Each suit stands over 7' tall and is manned by a genetically superior soldier called an Omega Warrior. The Omega Suit is a fully enclosed system which enhances strength, reflexes and senses of its wearer. Omega Suits can withstand tremendous amounts of damage and can carry enough firepower to lay waste to an entire division of conventional armored vehicles. Instead of sending tens of thousands of infantry to fight a battle, the same goal can be accomplished with a handful of Omega Warriors.

"Now, in the year 3000 AD, the war continues. Big armies, while maintained by the larger factions involved in the war, are seldom used. Most battles are fought by the Omega Warriors and where they go the ground trembles and the skies burn, for no target is out of their reach.

"Omega Warrior is a miniature rules set for creating the battles of the future using 6mm-28mm figures. Omega Warrior is a complete rules system, including rules for conventional infantry, vehicles, robots, AIs, and of course, the Omega Warriors themselves. Also included are army lists and a campaign system."

30588.name: Be My Lover
30588.description:
From the manufacturer:

To play, move your playing pieces along the game path picking cards. There are Intimacy Cards to direct you to either play an activity, ask your lover to play an activity, or have an activity completed together. In addition, there are Pleasure Cards that include sensuous pleasuring, intimate sharing and lots and lots of sex. A Spinner Game is included on the board to add random foreplay activities.

The game includes a game board, a deck of 55 Intimacy Cards with 157 different activities, a deck of 55 Pleasure Cards, 2 playing pieces, a spinner and instructions.

30589.name: Touring Europe
30589.description: Touring Europe is one of the travel board games by Geographia. Players start from London, and must race to reach their eight secret destinations located around Europe and return to London before their competitors. Along the way, players must negotiate customs checks and road blocks.

30590.description: This is a rummy variant themed on James Bigglesworth, better known as "Biggles", who is a fictional British WWI pilot and adventurer created by W. E. Johns. In addition to the rummy-based play, the game incorporates some storytelling through the artwork on the cards depicting Biggles in a variety of adventures.
30590.name: Biggles

30591.name: Cavalry Game
boardgameversion: De La Rue English first edition
30591.description:
This educational card game was intended to teach children "the names and numbers of the British cavalry regiments". The cards are illustrated with the various regiments, and the instructions note that: "It is taken for granted that the players know that there are seven Dragoon Guard Regiments". Players compete through drawing and exchanging cards to complete sets of the regiments, with the player completing the most regiments winning.

This game appears to have been published sometime between 1900 and 1920.

30592.name: Piotrków 1939
30592.description:
Polish Wargame about the battles around the city of Piotrkow during the German invasion of Poland in 1939.

Contains quite large hex-map of the area and something around 600 counters which have to be cut out first.

30593.name: Robin Hood Merry Card Game
30593.description: Robin Hood Merry Card Game has 48 cards depicting Robin Hood and members of his outlaw gang and villains from the story.

30594.name: Counties of England
boardgameversion: John Jaques Deluxe Wooden Box Edition
John Jaques Series 1: Northern Counties edition
John Jaques Series 2: Midland Counties edition
John Jaques Series 3: Eastern Counties edition
John Jaques Series 4: Southern Counties edition
30594.description:
This game's components are cards related to counties in England. Cards list the towns in that particular county and a varying number of town cards (from two to seven) that include illustrations of the town on them and include interesting facts such as main industries, attractions, and population. The game was released in four series, each covering a different region of England:

1st Series: Northern
2nd Series: Midland
3rd Series: Eastern
4th Series: Southern




Players compete to complete county sets by obtaining the set of relevant town cards. The winner is the player who completes the greatest number of sets.

The game is similar to Happy Families, also published by John Jaques of London.

30595.name: WarPaint
30595.description: Tactical miniatures rules for the American Indian wars.

30596.name: Grand Chess
30596.description:
Grand Chess is a variant played on a 10x10 board with two additional pieces; the Marshall (which combines the movement powers of the rook and knight, it's also called Chancellor) and the Cardinal (which combines the movement powers of the bishop and knight, it's also called Archbishop).

The setup has most of the pieces moved forward one rank from their "normal" position, with an empty rank behind that allows more freedom for the rooks and maneuvering of pieces.

30597.name: Hon slukades av vargen
30597.description: A game similar to "taboo". You are supposed to guess what word your partner are describing.

30598.name: Apostlaspelet
30598.description:
A family game that is based upon the New Testament. You travel around the Mediterranean Sea and visit all the famous cities from the Bible such as Corinth, Athens, Damascus, Jerusalem, etc. On your way, you answer Bible questions, survive uprisings, support the early church and convert unbelievers.
It is a basic roll-and-move game with some skill involved when answering questions.

30599.name: Webkinz Trading Card Game
30599.description: Webkinz Trading Card Game builds on the Webkinz collectible teddy bear craze. Aimed at children 8 and above, players work to complete "challenges" by playing action cards. The game is very relaxed and non-violent in nature.

30600.name: Monopoly: London Nostalgia Wooden Box
30600.description:
This special Nostalgia edition of Monopoly: London includes:


Nostalgic Game board with London properties
Vintage Chance, Community Chest and Title Deed cards
'Aged' Monopoly Money
Six antique Bronze finish tokens
Wooden houses and hotels
Built-in wooden banker's tray and storage area
Two ivory colored dice
Monopoly History

30601.name: DDR-Reise
30601.description:
DDR-Reise is the same concept as Journey through Europe or Deutschlandreise. Players must optimize their route to visit places in the German Democratic Republic (GDR - DDR in German).

Each player has a home city and draws five cards for other cities that they must visit. The first player to visit all their cities and return home wins. There are 52 city-cards and 52 five cards with random encounters to deal with.

As far as I know the game was available in West-Germany (also produced by a West-German company) during the short period following the initial opening of sections of the Berlin Wall in 1989 until the decision that the territory of the Republic would accede to the ambit of the Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany in 1990. As a result of the unification the German Democratic Republic officially ceased to exist.

30602.name: Grey's Anatomy Trivia Board Game
30602.description: Players take on the role of their favorite character and move along the Experience path, answering trivia questions and relationship scenarios along the way. For 2 - 6 players Ages 14 and up.

30603.description: This is a children's card game based on the theme of "The Famous Five," a fictional group of English children who appear in books written by Enid Blyton. The card game is basically a rummy variation incorporating storytelling through plot lines depicted on the cards. The cards incorporate story lines from the fourth, fifth and eighth titles in the Famous Five series. The game was reissued in 1978 with new artwork on the box and cards to coincide with the appearance of a short-lived television series based on the books.
30603.name: The Famous Five Card Game

30604.name: More Who's in the Bag
30604.description: This is an expansion to the game "Who's in the Bag" which is a bit like charades with some Taboo mixed in (and probably some other party games as well). This expansion adds cards with another 400 celebrities' names.

30605.name: Cleveland Sports Trivia
30605.description: This is a basic trivia game focused on sports relating to Cleveland, Ohio (USA) and can either be used as a card set for trivia games like Trivial Pursuit, or as a stand alone game. The game includes Cleveland sports trivia cards, spinner, score card pads,a pencil, and instructions.

30606.name: Cleveland Trivia
30606.description: This is a set of cards intended for use with Trivial Pursuit or other similar trivia games. All of the trivia questions related to the city of Cleveland, Ohio (USA). The question categories include: People, Business/Technology, Places, Culture/Entertainment, Fine Points, and Sports.

30607.name: Spin-A-Tale
30607.description:
"Let your imagination run wild, as you spin a terrific tale..."

This game comes in a yellow plastic case, which holds the spinner and cards, and has clips built into the side for score-keeping.

Players take turns spinning the spinner, which will display a number (4,5,6, or 7) and a happy or sad face. That player must then take that number of cards (which display words such as "witch", "gorilla", "Something used in the bathroom", etc.) and has one minute ("No timer included") to tell either a "happy" or "sad" story using all of the words, to receive one point. First player to five wins.

30608.name: The Great Pyramid
30608.description: The first player to climb to the top of the Great Pyramid becomes the Pharaoh and rules those beneath him. This game may be played by two, three, or four players. Each player moves around the board by rolling dice, following directions on the color coded hieroglyph cards and avoiding being sent to the tomb. A more refined rule set for adults is included. A brief history of ancient Egypt and a map are also included.

30609.description: A child's first crossword game. Sesame street theme, Ages 3 - 5.
30609.name: Sesame Street Scrabble

30610.name: North American Wild Flowers Card Game
30610.description: Card game that comes with 50 3 X 5 cards that hopes to teach children about the wild flowers of North America. Instructions and descriptions are in English and French. Features artwork from Roger Tory Peterson, Walter A Weber and Al Kremi.

30611.name: Monster Tykes
30611.description:
From the product description:

In Monster Tykes, players lead a Team of young fantasy Monsters or Heroes who just can't wait to grow up and be like their parents. Too anxious to wait, they bully other Teams around the town, in schoolyards, and underground caverns. The first Team to send the other home "Crying to their mommies" wins!

Home Page: http://www.monstertykes.com

30612.name: Jalokivipeli
30612.description:
The game consists of a board, up to six player tokens, a die and 88 cards which are shuffled and piled on the board squares according to the numbers in them. The topmost cards form a changing landscape on which the players move their tokens.
There are 17 different types of cards, ranging from collectible resources (stones, flowers, gold nuggets, small gems) to hazards (water channels, snakes) and helpful items (UFOs, four-leaf clovers).
The purpose of the game is to move on the board (in allowed directions), turn the cards (by paying or rolling a suitable number) and collecting resources. The game ends when all five big jewel cards have been found. When this happens, the player with the most points wins.
This simple-sounding game is actually quite innovative and even challenging.

30613.name: Matka Pohjoismaissa
30613.description: The players travel through Nordic countries: Finland, Sweden, Denmark and Norway – by drafting transportation cards from the deck and using suitable ones for moving to the next town. There are five different ways of traveling: an airplane, a boat, a train, a bus and walking. Not every place can be reached via every method, so tactics are required. The player who makes the trip fastest and returns to his starting town wins the game.

30614.name: In Pursuit of Nothing the Seinfeld Board Game
30614.description:
From the manufacturer:

We all have a friend like George, who is as cheap as the day is long. In this game, each of the players is having lunch with this "George," with the goal of contributing NOTHING to his lunch tab. Playing is simple:

Players, in turn, choose a question by value/difficulty. Answer the question right - transfer a portion of your contribution to another player (i.e., the value of the question). Answer the question wrong - another players transfers the value of the question to you. The first one to Nothing wins.

30615.description:
From the publisher:
Storm the walls of Rome, lay siege to Jerusalem!

Siege and Conquest is a rules expansion and source book for Warhammer Ancient Battles.

Throughout history, Sieges have decided the fates of nations. From the earliest Biblical times through the Roman period, the Crusades, the 100 Years War and into the age of gunpowder, peoples defended their walls from invaders looking for Conquest.

Cities have held out against invaders for years by stubborn resistance, others have fallen purely at the hand of a traitor or exchange of coin.

Featured within this book are the following:

SIEGE
A historical overview and full rules for siege warfare through the Biblical, Classical and Medieval Eras.

The siege section of this book allows you to recreate a full siege campaign using a series of 10 scenarios, or as many wargamers prefer, the option to just move to the final deciding assault!

By using the WAB points system, the besieger can create openings in the wall or undermine the fortification, whilst the besieged can attempt to shore up their beleaguered defences!

This will allow you to complete a siege game in a couple of hours.

CONQUEST
Scenarios and pitched battle variants as well as inspirational material for using terrain and weather in games, ideas for multiplayer games and developing your own campaigns of Siege and Conquest.

Also included are exciting new rules for fighting in settlements such as villages and cities.

These add a new level of tactical play on the tabletop in your games of Warhammer Ancient Battles.

A full colour section is included showing a range of fortifications across the ages, armies deployed for battle and explanations of the rules in action!

Besiege Constantinople, command Viking Raiders or defend the city of Troy.

When the enemy are at the gates and your walls are crumbling, will your army hold?

Expands

Warhammer Ancient Battles
30615.name: Siege and Conquest

30616.description:
From the publisher:
The Age of Arthur – Warfare in the British Dark Ages 400 AD – 800 AD is a source book for Warhammer Ancient Battles.

This exciting period of British history saw the foundations of England, Scotland and Wales laid down by the warring Saxons, Romano-Britons, Welsh, Irish and Picts.

Arthur himself may have led British resistance against the Saxons, but this supplement also focuses on the other great warlords of the age – including Cadwallon of Gwynedd, Vortigern of the Britons, and Ecgfrith of Northumbria – and their warbands.

This source book contains a suggested historical overview and chronology of the period, as well as 19 detailed army lists featuring:

The Romano-British Civitates – including the armies of Vortigern, Ambrosius and the Bretons.
The British and Welsh Kingdoms – including the kingdoms of Gododdin, Gwynedd, Strathclyde and Dumnonia.
The Saxons – including Saxon raiders as well as the kingdoms of the Heptarchy.
The Franks – the armies of the early Merovingians.
The Picts – including the Northern and Southern Picts, and the enigmatic Attecotti.
The Scots-Irish – including Irish raiders and the kingdoms of Dalriada and Ireland.
There is also a section on wargaming Arthur in history for those who wish to use the great hero in their armies! Accompanying each of the army lists are suggestions for collecting, painting and wargaming with the various armies that fought in Dark Age Briton.

Other resources include a full colour section portraying the armies of the time and a wealth of illustrations and maps.

This book contains 15 exciting scenarios and two full campaigns – Mount Badon and the Raiding Season – to help you recreate the atmosphere of early medieval warfare – The Age of Arthur.

AGE OF ARTHUR ERRATA
Despite the best endeavours of many people, a production gremlin created a couple of minor typos which sneaked through into printing. They are both in the Saxon section.

1. Page 50 - Saxon army list. The Saxon Gedriht (hearthguard) should be limited to 0-1 unit, like most of the other comitatus units in the book.

2. Page 53 - the Army of Ecgfrith, King of Northumbria. As printed, poor King Ecgfrith has a Ld of 2 and appears to cost only 10 points. This mighty Saxon warrior was, of course, somewhat more charismatic than this, and should have an Ld of 9 (as per the Saxon Cyning profile on page 49) and cost 210 points!

Expands:

Warhammer Ancient Battles
30616.name: Age of Arthur
boardgamefamily: The Legend of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table

boardgamehonor: 2006 Origins Awards Historical Miniature Game of the Year Winner
30617.description:
From the publisher:

1462: a Walachian prince and his small army stand alone against the military might of the Ottoman Empire. But this prince, Vlad Tepes, is no ordinary man: he succeeds in driving the best-trained army in the world from his homeland through a campaign of relentless terror. Employing a scorched earth policy, along with ambushes, night attacks, and the tactics of fear – by which more than 20,000 Turks were impaled on wooden stakes – he earns his bloody nickname “Vlad the Impaler,” and ensures his own immortality.

This source book contains an historical overview of the period and a chronology detailing the important events and battles from the age of “Vlad the Impaler” and the Ottoman Turks. It tells the true story of this controversial figure – who was both hero and villain – against the rich backdrop of Medieval Balkan history.

Expands:


Warhammer Ancient Battles
30617.name: Vlad the Impaler

30618.description:
Each player starts with a piece of paper and a pencil. At the top of the paper, each player writes a sentence. Then they pass the papers to their left. The next player "draws" the sentence a la Pictionary, then folds the paper so only the drawing is visible and passes it to their left. The next player looks at the drawing and writes a sentence that they think the drawing represents. This continues until all players have their original paper back. At the end, all players unfold their paper, and much hilarity ensues as "I am the Walrus, koo-koo-ca-choo" becomes "Hitler and I danced the night away in a disco."

The game continues until everyone runs out of paper or everyone has added something to each paper, always ending on a sentence.

Eat Poop You Cat does not comport with the BGG guidelines for what constitutes a game, but is kept in the database by popular demand and administrative fiat.
30618.name: Eat Poop You Cat
boardgamepodcastepisode: TPGC - Episode #2 - Pictionary, Telestrations and Ha! Ha! Moustache

30619.name: Spend Government Spend
30619.description: Roll and move board game produced in 1981 by Rolger inc. For 2 to 4 players. Ages 12 and up.

30620.name: Pinky Lee's New TV Game Who Am I?
30620.description: Based on the TV show that ran from 1954 to 1956, this is a children's game similar to charades that comes with 11 masks, a timer, crayons, and a wipe-off score card.

30621.name: Race of the Knights
30621.description:
A mighty, evil Knight has occupied the castle and taken the princess prisoner. Now, the most courageous knight in the whole country try to cross the moat as quickly as possible in order to free the poor princess.

There is a separate track for each player that leads to the castle. if a player rolls a 1-3 he can lay the corresponding number of bridge-cards along his track or move his knight. You can only move your knight on squares on which there is already a bridge card. If the player rolls the symbol "hand", he may steal any bridge-card from another player.

As soon as a player succeeds in moving his knight onto the last square on his track he has won.

The game includes a promotional playmobil(R)-figure.

30622.description:
Three Way Cube is a three-dimensional brain-twister. There are chances on all three levels.

The rules are similar to the rules of the mill-game. After the lots have been drawn for white and brown, each player receives 32 beads. Now both players by turn try to build up a vertical, horizontal or diagonal line. As soon as a player has built a mill he may take away a bead from his opponent. It is, however, only allowed to take beads which are seizable directly, that means which are on the top of a pin. If a mill is closed you may not take away a bead from his mill.

The aim of the game is to take all beads from the opponent or to block his beads in such a way that he cannot move any longer.

Similar to:

Score Four (though with different play and scoring)
30622.name: Three Way Cube

30623.name: Tavern Battle
30623.description:
This game begins when most of the role playing game ends.
The heroes are coming back from their adventures fighting monsters and gathering treasures. But still, the dwarf is missing his axe, the magician is looking for his book with new spells, the Elf wants his enchanted lantern back. So every character is looking for something important to him.
In the first phase of the game each player tries to get the item he wants back by negotiation. If that fails, well, then we will have a hefty battle in that tavern and one sure thing we know is that there will be not a single chair left intact after that fight.

This game consists of 110 cards (12 different characters like Trolls, Goblins, Paladin, Orc etc. and lots of items), dice and a rule book.

30624.description: Quickly make the right combinations and snatch first. Game for 2 players. Includes "The Brementown Musicians" fairytale.
30624.name: Brementown Musicians

30625.name: The Watergate Caper
